importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article indicates the current timeline of humanitarian crisis and aid delivery in Gaza, highlighting ongoing supply challenges under the ceasefire agreement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article focuses on the immediate state of food supplies in Gaza as of late October 2025, following the US-brokered ceasefire, emphasizing urgent humanitarian needs.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza are significantly below the WFP's daily target of 2,000 tonnes, with only 750 tonnes entering daily.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings (Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara) are currently open, severely limiting aid flow.
The WFP has 26 distribution points operational, far short of the 145 planned for the entire Gaza Strip.
Humanitarian aid continues to reach northern Gaza via southern routes, but not at sufficient scale; food supplies are enough for half a million people for two weeks.
Many Palestinians are storing food due to uncertainty over the ceasefire's longevity.
Hamas has pledged to return 28 bodies, having delivered 13 so far, and the Rafah crossing remains closed until further notice.
The US-brokered ceasefire and its 20-point plan are vital for enabling humanitarian access and preventing famine.
The WFP emphasizes that opening all border crossings is critical to meeting food needs and saving lives.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A United Nations agency responsible for coordinating global food aid efforts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to the reporting on food supply levels in Gaza, providing data, assessments, and calls for increased aid access through border crossings.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza, located in the southern part of the territory.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the two currently open crossings into Gaza, allowing food and aid to enter, but still insufficient to meet supply needs.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kissufim in Israel)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza, located in the central region of the territory.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the two operational crossings, enabling limited humanitarian access to Gaza’s central and southern areas.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its closure by Israel restricts access to Gaza’s northern regions and limits humanitarian access to northern Gaza, increasing food insecurity.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south street in Gaza that is currently not accessible for WFP food distribution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been granted permission to use this route, which would allow broader access to northern Gaza and reduce food shortages in the north.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian political and militant group that governs parts of Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is involved in the release of captured Israeli bodies, which is a condition for the ceasefire and humanitarian access to northern Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister who has stated the Rafah crossing will remain closed until Hamas returns the bodies of deceased captives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His position directly impacts the status of humanitarian access, especially through Rafah, and is a key political factor in aid delivery.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President who brokered the ceasefire and introduced a 20-point plan for ending the war in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His diplomatic efforts are central to the ceasefire and the promise of full aid access to Gaza, making him a key figure in the humanitarian response.

namedEntities.name: US-brokered ceasefire
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A truce agreement brokered by US President Donald Trump, intended to halt hostilities in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is essential for allowing humanitarian aid to enter Gaza, as the only mechanism currently sustaining the ceasefire and enabling food delivery.

namedEntities.name: 20-point plan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A US-proposed strategy for ending the conflict in Gaza, which includes full humanitarian aid access.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It outlines the framework for sustained aid delivery, including opening all crossings, and is a key policy driver in the current humanitarian situation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that food supplies to Gaza remain critically low despite a US-brokered ceasefire, with only 750 tonnes of food entering daily—far below the target of 2,000 tonnes—due to just two open border crossings: Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara. The WFP operates 26 food distribution points, far less than the 145 it aims to establish across Gaza. Humanitarian aid reaches northern Gaza only via southern routes, and the Rafah crossing remains closed, barring access to the north. Hamas has handed over 13 of 28 pledged bodies, but the situation remains fragile, with many Palestinians storing food due to fear of renewed conflict. The WFP stresses that opening all crossings is vital to prevent famine and save lives, with the US-brokered ceasefire and its 20-point plan serving as the foundation for sustained aid delivery.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
